item.title: E5 Coral
item.description:
The E5 Coral project is a collaboration between six labs at six U.S. universities, and uses reef-building corals as a model system to test the connections between physiological, epigenetic, and metabolic states, and predict how population and community dynamics are influenced by epigenetically-modulated phenotypes. Learn more at the project website!

Github

item.title: SIFP 2025
item.description:
Benchmarking Nanopore direct sequencing as a method for mapping hDNA methylation in archival coral specimens.

Work conducted at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, under the advising of Dr. Andrea Quattrini and supported by the Smithsonian Institution Fellowship Program (SIFP).

item.title: ceasmallr
item.description:
Venkataraman et al. 2024 exposed Eastern oysters (Crassostrea virginica) to ocean acidification treatments and examined the interplay between resultant differential methylation and differential gene expression.

In ceasmallr, we build on this work by evaluating the heritability of this environmentally-induced differential methylation in C. virginica. See project details and current status at the project Github, linked below!

Github
Date Title Categories Reading Time
Aug 7, 2025 Summary of completed ceasmallr work SIFP-2025 3 min
No matching items

item.title: Pacific Cod
item.description:
Github

Gene activity and genetic selection in Pacific cod reared under thermal stress

Juvenile Pacific cod will be reared in three temperatures under feeding and non-feeding conditions, then an integrated genomic approach will identify genes, gene variants, and epigenetic markers that respond to thermal stress and confer resilience. To complement the genomic approaches and further investigate temperature influences on energy resources, we will perform lipid analyses. This work will inform predictions of genetic selection and molecular response of Pacific cod in the Gulf of Alaska under climate change.

Date Title Categories Reading Time
